New-York Historical Society
Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission records
Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission
MS 314
20 Linear feet in 42 boxes
1905-1913 (Bulk 1909-1911) The Records of the Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission focus on the commission's role in orchestrating the Hudson-Fulton Celebration of 1909. The collection contains correspondence, contracts, vouchers, cancelled checks, financial and legal documents, meeting minutes, clippings, and ephemera.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of the Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission, 1911.
Access Restrictions
Open to qualified researchers. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.
Use Restrictions
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.
Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission Records, MS 314, New-York Historical Society.
Historical Note
The Hudson-Fulton Celebration was held September 25 - October 11, 1909 to commemorate the 300th anniversary of Henry Hudson discovering the Hudson River in 1609 and the 100th anniversary of the first commercial steamboat service, started by Robert Fulton in 1607. Communities along the River observed the celebration, with events occurring from Staten Island to Cohoes, New York.
In 1905, George B. McClellan, Mayor of New York City, and Francis W. Higgins, Governor of New York, appointed a committee of approximately 150 citizens to plan and implement a Hudson tercentennial celebration. The Mayor also formed a committee to plan a celebration honoring Fulton's contributions to the Hudson River region. In 1906, it was decided to merge the two committees and through the enactment of Chapter 325 of the Laws of 1906, the Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission was formed on April 27, 1906.
The commission was divided into several working committees, the number increasing from 12 in the first year to 51 by the time the celebration commenced. Some of these committees were the Aquatic Sports Committee, Auditing Committee, Historical and Carnival Parades Committee, Invitations Committee, Medal Committee, Naval Parade Committee, Plan and Scope Committee, Reception Committee, and Religious Services Committee.
The New York State government appropriated about 48 percent of the funds required for the celebration, while the New York City government contributed about 24 percent of the funds. Since the federal government did not provide financial aid for the celebration, nor did any other state governments, the remaining 28 percent of required funds came from private donations made to a subscription fund set up by the commission.
The celebration was intended to not only commemorate two significant historical achievements, but also encourage "civic pride," start a "historical awakening," "assimilate" the immigrant population, and promote "international friendship" and world peace. Dignitaries from throughout the world were invited to participate, and visitors filled New York hotels beyond capacity. The celebration included banquets and receptions, various parades throughout the city, aquatic competitions, and naval parades among other festivities. Wilbur Wright was hired to perform several aerial demonstrations during the celebration, flying along the Hudson River from Governor's Island to Grant's Tomb. Upon its conclusion, the Hudson-Fulton Celebration was described as a "jubilee of happiness," whereby New York enjoyed two weeks of peace, patriotism, and prosperity.
Scope and Content Note
The Hudson-Fulton Celebration Commission Records document the activities of the Commission from 1905 to 1913. The bulk of the material is from 1909 to 1911, the time in which most of the preparation and follow-up activities occurred. While the Invitation Replies subseries, as well as a few pieces of correspondence, do discuss the event's success, most of the collection focuses on preparation activites and the Commission's inner workings, rather than the celebration itself. However, The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission offer a detailed account of the Celebration, as well as insight on the event's successes.
The bulk of the collection is composed of correspondence and financial documents, particularly payment vouchers. The collection also contains legal documents, organizational materials, clippings, ephemera, and assorted materials unrelated to the Hudson-Fulton Celebration. There is very little visual material, as most of this is housed in the Print Room's collection (see Related Material).
Arrangement
The records are divided into 12 series:
Missing Title
Series I: Correspondence
Series II: Financial Documents
Series III: Legal Documents
Series IV: Organizational Materials
Series V: Ephemera
Series VI: Clippings
Series VII: The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission
Series VIII: Materials unrelated to the Hudson-Fulton Celebration
Related Material at The New-York Historical Society

Series I: CorrespondenceSubseries I.A. General Correspondence
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains both the internal and external correspondence of the Commission. While most of the correspondence is arranged alphabetically by sender, letters written by the Commission's secretary, Henry Sackett, and assistant secretary, Edward Hagaman Hall, are filed alphabetically by recipient. Invitation Responses
Scope and Contents note
This subseries consists of replies to the various events sponsored by the Commission, as well as thank you letters commending the Commission on a job well done. Most of the individuals invited to the Celebration and banquets were dignitaries and officials from the United States, as well as countries throughout the world.Invitation Responses, A-N1909 Sep-1909 Nov.133Invitation Responses, P-V1909 Sep-1909 Nov.134Acceptances for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.135Acceptances for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.136Acceptances for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.137Acceptances for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.138Acceptances for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.139Regrets for Astor Hotel Banquet1909 Sept.1310Acceptances for Governor's Island banquet1909 Sept.1311Acceptances for Governor's Island banquet1909 Sept.141Regrets for Governor's Island banquet1909 Sept.142Acceptances for Metropolitan Opera House banquet1909 Sept.143Thank you letters: Foreign countries, A-M1909 Oct.-1910 Feb.144Thank you letters: Foreign countries, A-M1909 Oct.-1910 Feb.145Thank you letters: United States (includes letter from President Taft)1909 Oct.-1909 Dec.146Subseries I.D. Scope and Contents
File of documents found on the shelf, separated from the collection. Added to the collection and finding aid in December 2021 by archivist Larry Weimer.Series V: Ephemera
Scope and Contents note
The ephemera in this collection consists of invitations, programs, tickets, and various other printed materials.Invitationscirca 1909331Printed materialscirca 1909332Programscirca 1909333Ticketscirca 1909334Public Health & Convenience Committee. Armbands and banners (rolled)circa 190936
Scope and Contents
4 banners (23x36 inches): Rest Station, Medical Station, Comfort Station, Information Bureau. 4 arm bands (4x9 inches): Information Bureau attendant, medical station, doctor, nurse. (Items found on shelf in manila envelope, apparently having been separated from the collection, in December 2021 and added to the collection/finding aid at that time by archivist Larry Weimer.) Textiles rolled and encapsulated by conservator Alan Balicki in December 2021.Series VI: Clippings
Scope and Contents note
This series contains magazine and newspaper clippings about the Celebration.Magazine Articles1909 Sept. 25-1909 Oct. 9335Newspaper Clippings1909 Apr. 4-1911 May 11336Series VII: The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission
Scope and Contents note
This series contains various drafts for The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission, 1909, many of which contain editing notes.Draft, Intro-Chapter X1910 May 21-1910 Dec. 27337Draft, Chapter XI-XXXVI1910 Jun. 30-1910 Jul. 27338Draft, Chapter XXXVII-XL1910 Jul. 19-1910 Aug. 2339Draft, Chapter LVI-LX1910 Jul. 17-1910 Aug. 23310Illustrationscirca 19103311Draft, Intro-Chapter XXIIcirca 1910341Draft, Chapter XXII-Lcirca 1910342Draft, Chapter LI-LXII, Appendixcirca 1910351The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission, volume 119104139The Fourth Annual Report of the Hudson Fulton Celebration Commission, volume 219104140Series VIII: Materials unrelated to the Hudson-Fulton Celebration
Scope and Contents note
This series consists of miscellaneous materials related to the collection, such as visiting cards collected at the various events, materials relating to Robert Fulton, obituaries of Commission members, and loose envelopes from the collection.Visiting cardsUndated352Handwritten notesUndated353List of members of the Board of Alderman1909-1911354Materials relating to Robert FultonUndated355Materials relating to Robert FultonUndated356Obituaries1909 Dec. 16-1911 Jun. 29357Scrapbook: Clarence Lexow obituaries1910 Dec. 31-1911 Jan. 1358Description of Lexow Family Coat of Armscirca 1911359The Journal-News - Articles honoring Clarence Lexow1948 Jun. 153510Manuscript copy from "The Homestead of a Colonial Dame" by Alice Crary Sulcliffe, 1909 (Robert Fulton's great-granddaughter)19093511Schedule of New York baseball games (used as place holders)19093512Loose envelopesUndated3513
